content.title: Restless Legs Syndrome
content.summary: Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the legs, typically accompanied by uncomfortable sensations that worsen during rest and in the evening/night, and are temporarily relieved by movement. Iron deficiency is a key modifiable factor, and dopamine agonists are first-line treatment.
key_points: Four essential diagnostic criteria: urge to move legs, worse at rest, relief with movement, circadian pattern
Associated with iron deficiency - check ferritin and treat if <75 μg/L
Dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole) or alpha-2-delta ligands (gabapentin, pregabalin) are first-line
Augmentation is a major complication of long-term dopaminergic therapy
Strongly associated with periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS)
Screen for secondary causes: iron deficiency, uremia, pregnancy, neuropathy
content.statement: Restless legs syndrome is a sensorimotor disorder diagnosed by the urge to move the legs accompanied by uncomfortable sensations, circadian worsening in evening/night, symptom provocation by rest, and relief with movement.

explanation.intuition: Imagine trying to sit still while your legs feel like they have 'electricity' running through them. The discomfort is deep, hard to describe, and the only relief is moving. Now imagine this happens every evening when you try to relax or sleep - that's RLS.
explanation.key_insight: RLS is fundamentally a dopamine and iron disorder. Brain iron is essential for dopamine synthesis (iron is a cofactor for tyrosine hydroxylase). Even 'normal' serum ferritin (<75) may indicate brain iron deficiency - hence the higher treatment threshold.
explanation.technical_details: The pathophysiology involves reduced brain iron in substantia nigra and other regions, leading to dopaminergic dysfunction. Spinal cord hyperexcitability contributes to sensory symptoms. PLMS occur in 80-90% of RLS patients and are recorded on polysomnography as repetitive leg movements during sleep.

definitions_glossary.restless_legs_syndrome: Sensorimotor disorder with urge to move legs, worse at rest and in evening
definitions_glossary.akathisia: Inner restlessness and inability to sit still; differs from RLS in lacking circadian pattern
definitions_glossary.periodic_limb_movements: Repetitive stereotyped leg movements during sleep (PLMS) or wakefulness (PLMW)
definitions_glossary.augmentation: Worsening of RLS symptoms from long-term dopaminergic therapy (earlier onset, spread to arms)
definitions_glossary.ferritin: Iron storage protein; target >75 μg/L in RLS
definitions_glossary.dopamine_agonist: Medication activating dopamine receptors (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine)
definitions_glossary.alpha_2_delta_ligand: Calcium channel modulators (gabapentin, pregabalin) used for RLS
definitions_glossary.sensory_symptoms: Uncomfortable sensations described as creeping, crawling, itching, pulling
definitions_glossary.circadian_pattern: Symptoms worse in evening/night due to dopamine rhythm
definitions_glossary.impulse_control_disorder: Behavioral side effect of dopamine agonists (gambling, hypersexuality)
definitions_glossary.polysomnography: Sleep study recording brain waves, leg movements, and breathing
definitions_glossary.Willis_Ekbom_disease: Alternative name for restless legs syndrome

pathophysiology.mechanism: Dopaminergic dysfunction related to brain iron deficiency

iron_dopamine_link.tyrosine_hydroxylase: Rate-limiting enzyme in dopamine synthesis; requires iron as cofactor
iron_dopamine_link.brain_iron: CSF ferritin is low in RLS patients even with normal serum ferritin
iron_dopamine_link.dopamine_rhythm: Dopamine levels naturally decline in evening - explains circadian pattern

IRLSSG_essential_criteria.criterion_1: Urge to move legs, usually accompanied by uncomfortable sensations
IRLSSG_essential_criteria.criterion_2: Symptoms begin or worsen during rest or inactivity
IRLSSG_essential_criteria.criterion_3: Symptoms are partially or totally relieved by movement
IRLSSG_essential_criteria.criterion_4: Symptoms occur exclusively or predominantly in evening/night
IRLSSG_essential_criteria.criterion_5: Not solely accounted for by another condition

supportive_features: Periodic limb movements during sleep or wakefulness

severity_assessment.severe: Most nights, significant sleep impairment, daytime symptoms

required_workup: Consider neuropathy workup if sensory symptoms atypical

differential_diagnosis: Peripheral neuropathy (sensory symptoms but not circadian)
Akathisia (inner restlessness but no circadian pattern; often drug-induced)
Nocturnal leg cramps (painful muscle contractions, not urge to move)

iron_supplementation.oral: Ferrous sulfate 325mg with vitamin C on empty stomach
iron_supplementation.IV: Ferric carboxymaltose 1000mg if oral fails or GI intolerant

alpha_2_delta_ligands.advantages: No augmentation risk; helps sleep; good for painful RLS

dopamine_agonists.risks: Augmentation (especially at higher doses), impulse control disorders

augmentation_management.definition: Earlier symptom onset, spread to arms, shorter relief from medication
prevention: Use lowest effective dopamine agonist dose
augmentation_management.treatment: Gradually taper dopamine agonist over weeks; switch to alpha-2-delta ligand or opioid

non_pharmacologic: Sleep hygiene and regular sleep schedule

definition.@value: A sensorimotor disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the legs, accompanied by uncomfortable sensations, circadian worsening, and relief with movement

scopeNote.@value: Covers diagnosis, iron deficiency link, pharmacologic treatment, and augmentation management

learning_objectives: Apply the four essential diagnostic criteria for RLS
Recognize the importance of iron status and treat if ferritin <75 μg/L
Compare dopamine agonists vs alpha-2-delta ligands for RLS treatment
Screen for secondary causes of RLS
clinical_pearls: Check ferritin FIRST - treat if <75 μg/L (not standard <30)
Alpha-2-delta ligands now preferred over dopamine agonists to avoid augmentation
Dose dopamine agonists LOW to prevent augmentation
Symptoms spreading to arms + earlier onset = augmentation
SSRIs and antihistamines can worsen RLS
common_misconceptions: RLS is a minor annoyance - it causes significant sleep deprivation and QOL impairment
Normal ferritin means no iron role - brain iron may be low even with ferritin 30-75
Dopamine agonists are always first-line - alpha-2-delta ligands preferred to avoid augmentation
